dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Back in 1927, H.L. Mencken called the United States the most boring place on earth, and honestly, that Democratic National Convention they described sounds like it lived up to that.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Back in nineteen twenty seven, H.L. Mencken called the United States the most boring place on earth, and honestly, that Democratic National Convention they described sounds like it lived up to that.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: He wrote in 1927: The United States, to my eye, is incomparably the greatest show on earth.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Right? No balloons, Oprah Winfrey somehow making it more depressing, and Mike Pence's scowl getting criticized—it's like they sucked all the joy out of the room on purpose.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Right? No balloons, Oprah Winfrey somehow making it more depressing, and Mike Pence's scowl getting criticized-it's like they sucked all the joy out of the room on purpose.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: It had everything: glitzy musical acts, rousing speeches, religious devotion, floods of tears, promises of hope, moments of joy, uplifting patriotism, Oprah Winfrey, and lots and lots of balloons. Television commentators marveled at the way Vice President Kamala Harris presented herself: her smile, her body language, her voice, even her choice of clothing.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: And it's not just an American thing, you know? The text points out that in Japan, where politicians are actually charismatic, voters still don't seem to care about that quality.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: And it's not just an American thing, you know? The text points out that in Japan, where politicians are actually charismatic, voters still don't seem to care about that quality.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Charisma plays a role even in countries like Japan, where most politicians are singularly lacking in that quality.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, but then it says Asian and European politicians are just as eager as Americans to present themselves as cold and unlikable. Like, why is that the strategy?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, but then it says Asian and European politicians are just as eager as Americans to present themselves as cold and unlikable. Like, why is that the strategy?
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: But overall, Asian and European politicians are not nearly as eager or as willing as Americans to sell themselves to the public as warm and loving human beings.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: It's so counterintuitive, right? You'd you want your leaders to be relatable, but instead they're out here performing disgust for their own families on stage.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: It's so counterintuitive, right? You'd you want your leaders to be relatable, but instead they're out here performing disgust for their own families on stage.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: But why, oh why, do candidates have to make such a show of loving their families? What does all that hugging and kissing on stage have to do with politics?

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Exactly! And it traces this back to monarchy—like how British kings and queens wanted to seem vile and aloof to stay unpopular. Queen Elizabeth I even banned the BBC from filming her private life.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Exactly! And it traces this back to monarchy-like how British kings and queens wanted to seem vile and aloof to stay unpopular. Queen Elizabeth I even banned the B B C from filming her private life.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Queen Elizabeth II allowed the BBC to document her domestic life, from barbecues in the garden to tea with the children. She felt that she had to come down to earth to remain popular.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: So in a way, American politicians are still playing that old royal game of pretending not to be like us, even though they totally are.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: So in a way, American politicians are still playing that old royal game of pretending not to be like us, even though they totally are.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: To ascend to the US presidency, with all its quasi-monarchical trappings, a candidate like the British royals must make a great show of being a regular guy or gal, a person like you and me, someone to have a beer with on the front porch.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: And then you see it to Hollywood—Oscar winners giving these detached, emotionless speeches instead of genuine ones. It's all about suppressing real feeling in public.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: And then you see it to Hollywood-Oscar winners giving these detached, emotionless speeches instead of genuine ones. It's all about suppressing real feeling in public.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Not the American stars, who must tearfully thank everyone from their primary schoolteachers to their pet dogs, and express their deep devotion to humanity.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Which is ironic because politics, just like filmmaking, is actually super collaborative behind the scenes. But the performance requires indifference.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Which is ironic because politics, just like filmmaking, is actually super collaborative behind the scenes. But the performance requires indifference.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Politics, like the Hollywood film industry, is in fact a ruthlessly competitive business, where private feelings ones own as well as those of others often must be ignored or suppressed to get ahead.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: So we end up celebrating gossip about their private lives because we want proof that their public coldness is an act. We want them to be inauthentic.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: So we end up celebrating gossip about their private lives because we want proof that their public coldness is an act. We want them to be inauthentic.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: We wish them to be, in a word, authentic.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: It's such a weird demand we place on them. No wonder these events can feel so hollow and, well, boring.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: It's such a weird demand we place on them. No wonder these events can feel so hollow and, well, boring.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Honestly, after reading this, I'm never gonna watch a convention or awards show the same way again.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Honestly, after reading this, I'm never gonna watch a convention or awards show the same way again.

artist_script:
HostA: Back in 1927, H.L. Mencken called the United States the most boring place on earth, and honestly, that Democratic National Convention they described sounds like it lived up to that.
HostB: Right? No balloons, Oprah Winfrey somehow making it more depressing, and Mike Pence’s scowl getting criticized—it’s like they sucked all the joy out of the room on purpose.
HostA: And it’s not just an American thing, you know? The text points out that in Japan, where politicians are actually charismatic, voters still don’t seem to care about that quality.
HostB: Yeah, but then it says Asian and European politicians are just as eager as Americans to present themselves as cold and unlikable. Like, why is that the strategy?
HostA: It’s so counterintuitive, right? You’d you want your leaders to be relatable, but instead they’re out here performing disgust for their own families on stage.
HostB: Exactly! And it traces this back to monarchy—like how British kings and queens wanted to seem vile and aloof to stay unpopular. Queen Elizabeth I even banned the BBC from filming her private life.
HostA: So in a way, American politicians are still playing that old royal game of pretending not to be like us, even though they totally are.
HostB: And then you see it to Hollywood—Oscar winners giving these detached, emotionless speeches instead of genuine ones. It’s all about suppressing real feeling in public.
HostA: Which is ironic because politics, just like filmmaking, is actually super collaborative behind the scenes. But the performance requires indifference.
HostB: So we end up celebrating gossip about their private lives because we want proof that their public coldness is an act. We want them to be inauthentic.
HostA: It’s such a weird demand we place on them. No wonder these events can feel so hollow and, well, boring.
HostB: Honestly, after reading this, I’m never gonna watch a convention or awards show the same way again.
